item.title: Oh the pain!!
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Well if there is one place I can safely bemoan my pains it's here in my blog, thats what most people use these things for right? Well just to keep up with the Jones my back is giving me some almight pain at the moment, wasn't doing too well on friday but then helped my mate Joel move on Saturday and been pretty much in pain ever since, I'm headingin in to yoga today so I'm hoping that will help to fix it up a bit. Stretching yesterday really helped anyway.

And just realised that I forgot to pick up the hard drive/ enclosure that I ordered on friday, gill is headed that way now to pick it up for me.

Peace out
J

item.title: Passport Woes
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Well I've managed to do it again. Apparently I'm incapable of keeping a passport for more than 6 months without immersing it in water or losing it completely!

So now I have to fly down to sydney to present my ugly mug at the consulate before they will start the paper work to get my replacement passport started. So I'm flying down next thursday at an obscene hour of the morning and I'm still $180 out of pocket not counting the $160 it costs for the replacement passport. I swear I'm going to have the bloody thing surgically attached to my body so I can never lose it again. There is definetly something to the entire biometrics thing! If I never had to worry about super-important identification papers like this again I'd take all the big brother shit that goes along with it.

On the plus side of things tho I do (apparently) have a job waiting for me in NJ, USA!!! I say apparently because the paper work is waiting on higher level management approval but the paper work has been started and I'm hoping to be able to get out of the country by late next month. I've got a lot of organising to do before I leave.

J

item.title: Getting Sick
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Sleeps left in Australia: 2

Went out to lunch with my mum and my little sister yesterday... went up to the Rue de Paris for some antipasto and pasta - along with too much coffee and way to much left over chocolate from easter :)

Today I spent the day wandering around Toowong getting last minute things sorted, meant to go over Liam's place but totally forgot - sorry dude! Got my tax return lodged - after the $100 fee they charge I'll still be getting a bit of cash back so that's (obviously) better than nothing.

Tried cancelling my comm bank credit card and found out it's a lot harder than you'd think. They are still processing charges from 9 days ago and until they finish processing them they can't give me a payout fee which means I can't finalise the card.... GRRR!!!! If it isn't sorted by tomorrow I'll crack the shits and let them have it heh :)

Going to go have 2 for 1 dinners at the Caxton with Joel, Sam, Sarah and Gill now.

Jamie out

item.title: Rockhampton
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Sleeps left in Australia: 3

Gill and I got back last night from Rockhampton and her friend Rollie's wedding. Twas a pretty interesting weekend, on our way to the (outdoor) wedding we were pelted with hail stones - apparently if we'd been a bit further out of town they were as big as golf balls.

Twas a lovely ceremony but we forgot to take a camera so no photos. People were getting pretty drunk at the reception so it's prolly a good thing that there were no photos :)

We got back to Bris at 6:30 and got a lift and leftovers from Sunday lunch -> Happy Campers!!!!

Kind of scary really... I wonder if I can pick up some cheap CC purchases while I am over there :)

Credit card signatures: useless?

SpaceAdmiral writes "Everyone should remember John Hargrave's classic Credit Card Prank on Zug. He tried signing fake names on his credit card receipt, and no one seemed to care. But that's nothing compared to The Credit Card Prank, Part 2. Can he draw obscene pictures instead of signing his credit card? Yes, it turns out. Is there any way of getting your signature checked? . . . Yes, it turns out. But you have to do an awful lot."

item.title: Party
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Had a top night last night... most of my good friends turned up to see us off. Thanks for making the effort everyone, and given we are at the top of a steep hill followed by three long flights of stairs it was a pretty big effort :)

I managed to get lots of pics - and I'm hoping that if Dylan is reading this he'll send me a bunch of his pics so I can post them up too.

Spent the day today cleaning up after said party and installing Ubuntu linux on my laptop. I'm typing this up on it now and it seems to a pretty sweet and easy install.  I had to get grub installed onto the MBR which I thought might be a bit of a problem for the XP install but it seems to be going ok in both modes. I've got gaim installed so that I can chat and thunderbird so I can email - both tested and working. As is my portable laptop - now if I could just get sound to work I'd be a very happy man.

Off to bed now catch you all later.

item.title: Byron Pics
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Well last night was a total riot, Amelia and Shannon (from Bon Scotts) had driven back up to brisbane for a bit of respite from touring and I hitched a lift with them when they came back to Byron. We got down to the Great Northern just before the boys went up to do a sound check.

It was the first time that I'd heard the guys playing as Bon Scotts and I was pleasantly suprised. I thought that the sound was a bit reminescent of Gersey and Art of Fighting. Liam would SO fit in down in Melbourne.

The Fagan (or Faagan as it was misspelt on some shows) gig was pretty spectacular aswell, lots of peeps on stage and a big full sound. Plus I got to drink their rider so I was pretty happy. Then Dom gave me a lift back to Brisbane last night which was fricking awesome - and he remembered where I lived which is even better considering I was passed out pretty good in the back of the car :)

I'm trying out posting pics from last night... more later

item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Well last night was a very scary experience for me, the first time that I've f'ed up something on my linux box that wasn't revertable :(

I was playing with the sudo (super user do for the unitiated - basically the only way to do any thing of importance) and managed to break it. So I needed to use this same thing I just broke in order to fix the thing i just broke.... Catch 22 and no way out without some serious hacking - and booting from cd.

Got it fixed about 12:30.... margarita(s) we had last night probably didn't help :)

Went with my flat mate and some of his college buddies for a steak and $1.50 margaritas. Had fun, haven't been getting out much as I've said before... got some pictures which I'll post seperately.

item.title: Music Finally
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Well it took most of the weekend, not counting the time I spent in at work, to get it working but it is up and running. What am I talking about you might ask, why my personal music server streaming out music to all comers! Well those comers who are on our wireless network anyway. My flatmate has this cool little device which will access content on a server (my laptop) and play it out through the stereo. It is currently playing through the TV but it still sounds a whole better than playing out of my laptop speakers.

I went out with my flatmate and his girlfriend to some of the local bars in Princeton. We had a great time drinking shots of Jagermeister and playing darts, it was nice to get out of the house. I haven't really done anything much since I been here in the US mainly due to a lack of knowing anyone who is not also an engineer.

I had to pay for it this morning tho when my boss called me in to work. He went out and bought us lunch though which was a nice change. Apparently my fortune cookie thinks I have the beginnings of a gambling problem and was so kind as to warn me from straying down that path. Thank god for that :)

I'm thinking of buying myself one of the HD based audio players out there but am having trouble deciding. The sony players look awesome but I've heard bad things about the bundled software (for which there is no alternative and no linux substitute - kind of an issue as I hate having to boot into windows). There is of course always the Ipod but the battery life is about half that of the sony offering albeit with 3 times the storage.

Matt also mentioned these tidy little players, 1 Gb, FM radio and 50 hours of play time.... only $200 and all in the size of a stick of gum.

item.title: Yay for housing!!!
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Well for those of you following the trials and tribulations of a 2 hour commute each day, good news is at hand. I think I have just found my new apartment!!!!

I went over there tonight after work and the guy is nice, he's an IT graduate so we should get along well. Place is decently size and moderately priced, he even took 100 off the price because I asked nicely.

It's second story with a back deck that looks out over a lake (awesome for summer), it's close to work (< 2 miles) and I even get my own bathroom (score). There is no living room furniture yet but my bedroom has a bed and the living room HAS A MASSIVE PLASMA TV AND X-BOX!!!!

I'm in heaven! Should be moving in on Sunday, I'm going to take Darren and Sally out for dinner tomorrow for being such sports and putting up with me for so long.

Anyways off to bed before getting up at 5:30 again tomorrow (hopefully for the last time)

item.title: Sushi for dinner
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Had awesome sushi for dinner tonight (as the title says). First time I've had tofu over here and it hasn't tasted like boiled plastic.

Was wondering when I'd find time to go open up a bank account, when I wandered up to the cafeteria, which is in the building I work in, and found a desk setup looking for new bank accounts. Thats right a bank wanting me to sign up for an account... free Checking (what they call a savings account) with free internet banking and free debit card. AND if I get my salary deposited directly into this account (50), set up and pay some bills online (25), use my debit card three times (25) or any combination of the previous they will give me free cash up to $100 (50+25+25). Sweet huh and I didn't even have to go anywhere :)

This time Darren and his fiancee Sally came along and we all kicked about together - we went to a broadway show on Saturday night which was really good fun. We saw Chitty-chitty bang bang and I paid $8 for half a small plastic cup of wine - ah the joy of playing in manhattan :)

Today we went to the pallisades mall which is apparently the second biggest in the states, bought a jumbo pack of razor blades (at a great deal less than the $5 a blade you normally pay) and picked up a new shirt. Loving consumer life.

No photos this time as I left my camera at home but I think last week was enough photos of NY anyway. Hope you all have a great week, I dont seem to be able to post much during the week (mainly because I don't do much during the week - except complain about work).

Ciao

item.title: Images and the Semantic Web - Part 2
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
semantic web

Well that just bites for the second time tonight I've lost a considerable amount of posting!!!! GAH!!!! This time due to firefox crapping out on me while I was editting. Goodbye 20 min musings (not much time but I wanted to get this done before going to bed)

Anyways....

I've been doing a fair bit of research into the association of information with other information (metadata) and in particular the association of some semantic information with digital image data. While I was using adobe photo albumn to organize my personal photos I associated a lot of data (captions etc) with my images. Unfortunately this didn't translate well when I decided that Picasa was the bomb and that I'd rather use that instead thank you so very much.

Hence my fascination with the use of EXIF data to store information about my images within the images themselves. The EXIF data associated with an image is normally used (by casual digital photographers at least) to store information generated by the camera. this can include such information as whether the flash fired, the amount of white balance, the distance from the camera of the main subject, which direction is up (if your camera has a gravity sensor). It can also be used to store descriptions of the image itself.

This however tends to be more the domain of the IPTC embedded data. The IPTC tags are a way for (professional) photographers to associate descriptions, captions, authorship and copyright notices with their images in digital format (in a manner which can't be easily seperated from the image itself). Actually this is misleading, it is easy to strip this information from an image if you are thus inclined but by being in the same file inadvertent loss is reduced.

This standard is currently being superceded by the Extensible Metadata Platform (XMP) standard. I say standard but it is actually in main the work of one company (Adobe) which brought this platform to life. The XMP is based upon the Rich Data Format (RDF - sick of my use of abbreviations yet?) and is meant as a consistent crossplatform framework for storing metadata about an image.

I'm still doing my research on this area and would like to get more involved, especially at the level of briding the gap between what are abstract concepts and the majority of digital imaging users. I'd welcome any comments from people who are reading this if any of my assumptions or conjectures are bogus. You can reach me at jimi_cook at hot mail.com - I am hoping to either motivate bloglines to allow comments or to move to a service which does provide this functionality.

Now for bed.

item.title: Images and the Semantic Web
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
semantic web

I've also been playing with my Ubuntu linux desktop trying to find some good photo organizing software. I came up with a couple of pretty cool pieces of software.

The first I found was GQview which seems to be a fairly solid piece of work built up from gimp. My only complaint would be the fairly slow load time for thumbnails. At least for the initial pass of a directory anyway, after that it caches them which improves the situation (there is still a situation tho). It does however seem to be one of the lightest solutions, it loads the interface in next to no time and doesn't seem to unecessarily load down the cpu....  unlike our next contender.

f-spot I found in the last place I looked, no not under the cushions on the sofa, but in the Graphics directory on my main menu. Apparently it comes pre-loaded with Ubuntu linux. It is a bit less mature than GQview being only up to the 0.12 version but for that it seems like an excellent piece of software.

It is based off the great (but sadly windows only) Picasa software which is being touted (and funded?) by Google and Flickr. It doesn't have the same level of functionality that Picassa does (hey it's only version 0.12) but the interface seems to have been taken exactly from the picasa drawing board. Given the overlap and quick time to product that I'm seeing with f-spot I wouldn't rule out the possibility that there was some contribution from the picasa developers. That is just conjecture on my part though - don't take it too seriously.

The third option I trialled was Gwenview. I was reluctant to install this option as it is based on the KDE desktop and I am running a Gnome desktop but I bit the bullet and installed the KDE dependencies that gwenview required and gave it a bash. It loads a lot slower than GQview (understandably) but once loaded is slick and loads thumbs and previews quickly (even on this old Toshiba TE2000 Im running on). Like the others it still has limitted support for the EXIF tags which I so desperately want to edit.

In conclusion, all are decent pieces of software but don't really come close to the image databasing tools you can find on windows (ie adobe photo albumn, picasa). I'm thinking I'm going to give f-spot and gqview a bit more of a look in. I've downloaded code for the former and am trying to get a handle on how it all fits together - kind of hard as it is written in mono and I have no experience whatsoever in csharp. It seems to have the best road map for getting meta data tag functionality tho so I'll stick with it until it is more whole.

In my next post I'll rant a bit more about why I want to be able to edit these tags easily.

Jamie

item.title: Been a while
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Well I have been pretty bad about updating my blog of late so I guess I'd better bring you all up to speed (coz I know that you were hanging out to hear what I've got to say)

Last weekend Robbie came over to visit on his way up to Montreal for the NIST speaker recognition workshop. He arrived on Friday afternoon after work and left just before work on Monday morning and we managed to squeeze some good drinking into a pretty short time :)

Friday was drinks in the town of princton, followed on Saturday by a walking tour of the borough. That was pretty cool actually, it's something I'd been meaning to do, but by actually living here, never gotten around to. There are some pretty parts of princeton and we got some exercise, it really was a win-win. We went home chilled out and then went back to town for some hot thai food (or so we thought), but the thai people were pretty rude and told us "Take out only" - the only three words they knew apparently. So we went next door to the indian restaurant, where they were much more civil (and cooked a mean curry). First time I've had Indian food like I'm used to it since I've been here (no offence to anyone living in Phili, but the indian food there sucked ).

We then went back to the bar from last night and reaffirmed that pretty much all their beers were poured from the same barrel of (poorly brewed) pilsner. The one notable exception was the beer which had strong traces of banana essence (but we are pretty sure they just added that after they got it from the same barrel).

Then on Sunday we went down to the shore (which is what they call the beach). Although having said that it is pretty much nothing like a beach as we Australians are used to it. The first thing you notice is the carnival type atmosphere, there are all sorts of side show type attractions on the boardwalk trying to seperate you from your money. In fact most things there are designed to perform said seperation - the beach itself costs you $6.50 to get on it. I was flabergasted, luckily I was with the highly flamable Rob, so we had a pretty good excuse to  go and chill in the pub until my flatmate and his girlfriend were ready to go home - as far as I'm concerned a great outing to the beach (shore).

Now my fingers be sore from typing so I'll leave the plans for my upcoming trip to California for next time. Promise it won't be so long this time.

JC out.

item.title: Got Telemarketers?
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded: Telemarketers make use of a telescript - a guideline for a telephone conversation. This script creates an imbalance in the conversation between the marketer and the consumer. It is this imbalance, most of all, that makes telemarketing successful. The EGBG Counterscript attempts to redress that balance.

item.title: update
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Well all, don't really have a lot to report this week, had a bit of a crazy weekend last weekend (again) so this weekend I've been keeping a bit of a low profile. We had some friends around on friday night but apart from a lack of sleep it was pretty tame.

I've been playing with my mum's new laptop for the major part of the weekend, if you are reading this mum - you might not be getting this thing :) Matt's TV is totally kickarse and can handle the video output of the laptop, so I've been running my little dual screen office set up most of the weekend.

Let me explain more, right now I am typing this on the laptop LCD while media player plays an albumn on the TV screen. Nice big visualisations going on and sound piped through the bigger and better speakers (compared to the laptop speakers). And last night Matt decided to check out the latest subscription service from Rhapsody Inc. Once signed up (free trial - normally $13/mnt), you get download access to the 300 odd movies which are currently playing on the starx movie network FOR DOWNLOAD!!! So last night he downloaded the chinese flick Hero and watched it on the big TV and it looked incredible, slightly below DVD quality but not much below.

The movie is pretty damn good too, not the fastest moving but tragically epic in the traditional chinese style. The use of colour throughout the movie was absolutely breathtaking aswell, it was directed by Yimou Zhang (who also did "House of flying daggers") and I have to say that I've been impressed by both offerings.

Anyway thats about all from me for now, watch hero if you get a chance.

item.title: Birthday Bash
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Hey everyone, that is if anyone still reads this now, prolly not but at least I'm still reading. I had my 25th birthday on Friday and despite thinking that it would be a bit of a dud affair I managed to get a jam packed weekend happening, thanks to the 4th of July celebrations which spread it out to 3 days of fun.

Friday

Work finished up nice and early and I went out with a couple of my workmates to get a late afternoon climb in. Hadn't been for a while but still managed to knock out a couple of good climbs, also makes for a nice natural high before I went out in Manhattan for a decidedly chemical high. My flatmate got a bit of a crew together and we cruised over for dinner and drinks in a couple of sweet bars around his little brothers apartment on the east side.

Saturday

Woke up feeling pretty hot in a small NY apartment and made it feel a bit better with a bunch of good coffee the next morning and some great eggs benedict. Pity about Davenport losing the Wimbledon finals but can't have everything.

Once I got back to princeton after some shopping, I had dinner and went out to a cowboy type bar and stayed out until a bit too late.

Sunday

Did nothing except cleaning up my apartment, grocery shopping and washing clothes.  Nothing doing !  Sweet!

Monday

Monday started out slow, but it was 4th July so I had to do something. So I got a call from my man Chris with a wacky tubing idea, we ended up sitting in the hot sun on an inner tube floating down the delaware river at a very leisurely pace.

Then went back to his place for a bbq with his family which was a nice little slice of American Pie. Then two of his friends, Megan and BJ, came over and picked us up for a trip into Philli. We got to see some awesome acts for free on the steps of the Art Museum, Bryan Adams (stoked... not), Rufus Wainright and the real reason that I went ..... Elton John! I know I could get some shit from people about that but I couldn't pass up the opportunity to see someone influential and inspirational to so many people. And he was excellent! truely sensational.

Anyways, it's now Tuesday night and I've hardly slept so I shall leave you with that little peek into my birthday weekend.

Ciao
Jamie

item.title: Katrinas Real name
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
I know it is cynical of me, but the recent coverage (at least here in the states) of Katrina's destruction hasn't exactly ellicited a great tide of sympathy from me. Talk of insurance payouts and oil price hikes along with some local mayor uttering the words "this is our tsunami" have all combined to leave a bit of a sour taste in my mouth. Another great quote was this one by Gov. Haley Barbour (Miss.) "It looks like Hiroshima is what it looks like," describing parts of Harrison County.

But I think that there are a few principal factors preventing me from feeling empathy :
  • The fact that the entire city is built below sea level on a storm ravaged coast
  • That the buffer zone of marshlands which would normally protect the city have been stripped away by artificial redirection of the mississippi.
  • The fact that there is no acknowledgment that storms such as these are a direct product of global warming (which americans contribute greatly too and yet fail to even recognise it's existance)
This article gives some extra information on my last point.

item.title: Swift Boating Science
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:

Chris Mooney skillfully uncovers the Bush era's institutionalization of spinning, distorting and ignoring science in The Republican War on Science. Book review by Brian Alexander.

item.title: Take it easy big
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Interesting piece... I've seen enough reports on how much Katrina is going to cost insurers and how it is going to affect oil prices.



as NBC reported, "some residents said they were caught off-guard by the gathering storm?"

...

Forget nature; the real problem is human nature.

Most people living on the Gulf Coast simply prefer to take their chances. So do Californians who live on the slippery bluffs of Malibu.

And San Diegans? Even after the devastating 2003 firestorms that marched from Cuyamaca to Scripps Ranch and back again, we seem to prefer denial and deflection.

item.title: Sunny Biking
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Today I had a chilled out day, managed to actually get a full 8 hours of sleep, which was a delicious change of pace. Then apartment cleaning chewed up what remained of my morning - that just left a beautiful sunny afternoon to take my new bike out and explore some more of princeton.

Once I got out there I realised that I should definetly have taken my camera becuase the countryside was really pretty - but then again pretty doesn't naturally translate to picturesque so maybe it's just better to describe. So then I went and hung around the township of princeton, managed to keep my impulse for espresso down to an iced green tea and an iced herbal tea. Now I'm off to play a game of tennis and see if I can keep the slight tan that I managed to acquire while on holidays.

Oh and we got a new espresso machine at home, tis way snazzy - seperate foam control knob and everything :) Life is good!

item.title: Back in Jersey
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Well I am now officially returned from holidays, I had my first day back at work on Friday and am now enjoying a nice buffer weekend.

California was so sweet, we were staying with my dad in Chico and had a sweet setup in his pool house. The heat was pretty full on, got up to 106 (41) at one point and was consistently around the 105 mark, translation for celcius - HOT!! But it was a nice dry heat which made it very bearable, as did the swimming pool and fridge stocked with beer (mmm mexican beer - much better than the swill americans call beer)

Got to hang out with my sister Alisa heaps and her young ward Johnathon. He is a lovely young man just turned 13 and has grown like a weed since the last time I saw him. Lovely manners but I think he lost a pair of boardshorts that I lent him - bugger.

Also got to hang out with my other sister Annette, who had just had her birthday. We all went up to the penthouse of Waynes new hotel and had a big do up there with a whole bunch of their friends, I started too early and had to crash out about 11 (this probably won't suprise too many people but it is actually the exception rather than the norm now).

San Francisco was the last port of call before returning and it was a great stop over. The hotel we stayed in was f'ing lush - we got upgraded to a suite and I seriously did not want to leave at the end of it. We got dolled up and went out on Union Street had some great sushi, enjoyed lots of fine beer. Then woke up early (and bleary eyed) the next morning for some serious shopping, got some new jeans to replace the pair I bought last time I was in SF (stolen from my washing line thank you very much). Then went to Haight street shopped drank and ate until it was time to go to the airport, was a very hip and groovy place. It was apparently the official headquarters of flower power back in the sixties and still had a good vibe to this day, they had this vaporiser room with the door open and the smell of pot was overpowering. No one cared! Sweet!

Anyway, shaping up to be a good weekend too, went to yoga for the first time since being here and met a new friend. But I'll save all that for my next post.

Jamie Out

item.title: Resources
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Face Recognition

There are some great Face Recognition resources available on the internet, I find a good place to start is face-rec.org, especially their comprehensive coverage of the many face databases that are available. Recently I also found some additional Annotations of selected databases provided by Tim Cootes for use with Active Appearance Models (AAM).
  • Manual annotation of the BioID face images.
  • Manual annotation of the XM2VTS face images.
  • Manual annotation of the AR Face Database face images.
  • Images with annotation of a talking face.

item.title: About Me
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded: My name is James Cook, but I prefer to be called Jamie so as to avoid the obvious comparisons that arise when you share a name with the person who is credited with discovering Australia. That is me over there on the left, I'm a software developer / manager / research engineer from Brisbane, Queensland, Australia.I currently work for Veitch Lister Consulting, managing their R&D team to help deliver transport modelling software. Previously I completed my Elec. Engineering PhD in the field of 3D Face Recognition at QUT where I also did my Bachelor of I.T. and Bachelor of Electronic Engineering. I haven't worked in that disciplinesince moving to the field of traffic and transport forecasting but if (for some strange reason) you are interested in my work, a list of my publications is available for your perusal. I also have two beautiful daughters, but because this site is for my technical interests I'll save all those photos for my google+ stream.

item.title: Setting up git deploy on ec2 with babushka, capistrano
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Step 1 Boot the server and give it some initial config * rvm installed * add user for your application * rvm and appropriate rubies installed for your application user * babushka installed
Step 2
* make sure nginx is running ** sudo babushka benhoskings:'running.nginx' ** sudo babushka benhoskings:'postgres access' **
babs benhoskings:'vhost enabled.nginx' path=~/current vhost_type=unicorn domain=... babs benhoskings:'vhost configured.nginx' path=~/current vhost_type=unicorn listen_host=0.0.0.0 domain=... babs benhoskings:'unicorn running' env=production

item.title: New York, New York
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Well I'm a bit late with my posting but I've had an action packed weekend so I shall endeavor to give you all a taste of it. Started out with some hijinks planned for NY with my friend JP, this all went smoothly, we hit the Lower East Side and found some interesting drinking holes, some of which were even "cheap" (ie less than $5 a beer. We met up with some of his friends and played some pool (even winning the occasional game) then had some good ol' NY pizza (best enjoyed at 4am). I then decided that it would be just as easy to catch a train back to my own bed as stay at Jason's place so I went to Penn Station to catch the first of the morning which left at 5:15. I made this safely and thought that all my problems were over, wake up before my station and catch a cab home, be all done in less than 80 minutes.... oh how wrong I was.

Turns out that all the rail networks on the east coast, I heard from Boston to DC quoted by someone, were being affected by some broken power line and that the trains weren't running. Now back in brisbane this has happened before, the city council normally re-routes some buses to run parallel to the train lines so that people can still get to their destination. Not so in New Jersey, even though the trains and buses are both run by the NJT, there didn't seem to be a single person taking control of the situation. After hanging around in Newark for about 2 1/2 hours I was finally informed that I could catch two buses and end up in a town about 20 miles from home - what do I do when I get there I asked, "that is up to you" was the reply. Welcome to Jersey.

So anyways as it turns out when I do finally get down to the bus stop they have managed to route a special bus that will take me to said town without having to connect. There I catch a bus that gets me within 3 miles of my house at which point my very hung over flat mate kindly picks me up. I walk through the door 3 minutes shy of midday.

Total travel time : 6hr 42min

I shall tell you all of my much more enjoyable sunday trip into NY after I get home from work

item.title: Cursing as Peephole Into Brain Architecture
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded: The New York Times offers this excellent and entertaining writeup on cursing and its role in recent studies of the brain. The article discusses the universality of cursing across time, space, and culture, its varied roles, from linguistic evolution to anger management, and its uses in recent brain research. You can also read all about the sexual effects of uttering obscenities and the swearing habits of sorority women." From the article: "Researchers point out that cursing is often an amalgam of raw, spontaneous feeling and targeted, gimlet-eyed cunning. When one person curses at another, they say, the curser rarely spews obscenities and insults at random, but rather will assess the object of his wrath, and adjust the content of the 'uncontrollable' outburst accordingly." As someone who plays a lot of MMOGs, in my experience this is only mostly true.

item.title: Working Weekend
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
It is a lovely sunny sunday and I am sitting (for the second day in a row) in my office and wanting to go home. I have finished my work for the day and I am currently in the process of booking my flights back to Australia though so it is not really too bad.

Looks like I'll be coming back on sunday the 4th of December, at around 7am in the morning. Bit of a shitter about the early start esp. since Gill is organizing a big concert for the night before but it was either that or come back even later in the week.

Been seeing some really good photos up on flickr recently, I've joined a fire twirling group and seeing all these pictures of flames is making me want to get into it even more. Can't wait to get back to Aus and get some of my own pictures up there.


I've been boring so that is about it for posting now, I'll leave you with a scary shot Gill took pre undead party. An even scarier thought is "If they looked like that before the party, what did they look like the morning after the party ..... ?"

item.title: Rope Swing
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Poor form on keeping a regular post I know but ..... well I have no excuse really so I'm just going to tell you all about the latest adventures I've been having.

Yesterday my buddy Chris and I trekked along the muddy banks of the delaware river looking for a rope swing that a friend had recommended and given (shitty as it turns out) directions to. So we almost turn back after having walked about two miles but decided to press on and were rewarded with the most beautiful little slice of river life. This rope swing had to be secured 30 meters up into a huge tree and we were swinging from about 10 off the water... meaning that when we let go we were pretty close to 10 meters above water level. Appartently my face was pretty funny as I was falling and I suddenly realised that "hey shouldn't I have hit water by now???"

I also managed to hurt myself pretty bad.. I have an incredible rope burn on my bicep which I shall endeavour to post photos of (yes it is that bad that it warrants online photos). I also think I sprained my ring finger (how I did that or why I bothered to write this escape me now). Anyways, adventures, good fun... I think we'll go do it again today.

Peace out

item.title: AJAX Programming
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
<geek>
This looks like an interesting method for storing a more significant amount of data on a client machine when developing AJAX (Asynchronous JavaScript and XML: for the uninitated it's the techonology used to develop new web applications, Google's GMail and maps.google.com among them).

The AJAX MAssive Storage System (AMASS) uses a hidden flash applet to allow JavaScript AJAX applications to store an arbitrary amount of sophisticated information on the client side. This information is permanent and persistent; if a user closes their browser or navigates away from the web site, the information is still present and can be retrieved later by the web page. Information stored by web pages is private and locked to a single domain, so other web sites can not access this information.

</geek>

item.title: Shell goodness
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
<Geek Alert>

As we all know the linux shell has been one of the stand out major differences between the windows and linux user experience. Some people are terrified at the thought of giving up their "intuitive" object oriented gui, while propents of the command line interface talk of how much more flexible and powerful a textual representation can be.

Having used a lot of shell scripting in my time persuing my PhD it is somewhat of a disappointment every time I am forced to use windows and it's antiquated CLI. However after reading this review on Ars Technica on the new Microsoft Shell for windows it looks like an alternative to cygwin is finally here. The command set seems to be very powerful and extendable and incorporates many of the best features from such scripting languages as perl, SQL, ruby and bash. Although with cygwin I do enjoy knowing that scripts I write will be cross platform right from the get go, who knows perhaps someone will release an interpreter for linux :)

</Geek Alert>

item.title: The Long Tail
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Just been reading up on this very informative article about the current changes in consumer behavoiur which are set to revampt the current distribution models employed by media outlets from music/movies through to books.

item.title: Slacker
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
I've finally got some time to sit down and post up the continuation of my previous posting (New York, New York). After wasting half a day discovering the joys of the Jersey bus system, I decided on Sunday that in all likelihood it wouldn't happen again and that another trip to NY was in order. The motivation for testing my luck? The white stripes and the shins both playing in a baseball statdium on Coney Island. Took about 2 1/2 hours to get down there (and back) but that was just the normal trip time no special delays - So it was a fairly time intensive trip.

Once i got there I bought my ticket and went in when i discovered that I'd been given a ticket up in the nose bleeds and couldn't change it for one closer to the stage (even though both types of tickets were on sale still and for the same price) so I ended up bribing one of the security guards standing between the two sections and got up nice and close to see the Shins. If you are unfamiliar with their music I'd recommend checking them out, they really are the entire reason that I went... the white stripes are good enough and all but if the shins hadn't been there neither would I. So got home at 1:30 and went to work early the next morning - another tired week at work but worth it for the shins.

There was actually another concert there today (Beck and Belle & Sebastian) which I would have loved to go to but it was simply too far and I had a paper due. But U2 are playing next weekend and I have tickets so i'll have to make do I guess. At work at the moment and about to go rock climbing so I should wrap it up there. Have a good week all.

item.title: More Sony Shennanigans
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
God sony music make me angry!!! Plus this one from slashdot - "Sony Warned Weeks Ahead of Rootkit Flap" from which the following comment was shamelessly stolen:

Lest we forget, Sony is still shipping CDs with SunnComm's MediaMax [ciocentral.com] DRM on them -- ten times as many as the XCP rootkit, in fact (that's 20 million CDs at last count, for those keeping score at home). It's still just as easy to defeat as it was in 2003 [slashdot.org], but if you make the mistake of letting it install like my wife did, it's fairly nasty. In particular it actually installs before you agree to the EULA -- the only difference between agreeing and declining is that if you decline, the software is not activated (but it remains installed).

If you have a device driver named Sbcphid.sys (which shows up as a hidden non-plug-and-play device named Sbcphid when active), you've got MediaMax and should remove it [cdfreaks.com].

Only the EFF [eff.org] has mentioned MediaMax in the various legal claims against Sony, and Sony has remained silent about it in public as well. Obviously they're not sorry about using DRM at all -- they're just sorry they got caught.

item.title: Chilling Effect
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
You've all probably heard at some point or another mention of the shining beacon in the great American fight against piracy that is the DMCA (Digital Millenium Copyright Act). If you read the same news sources I do then you will probably not have heard it mentioned in a greatly flattering context, among the hubub surrouding this contentious piece of legislation some hard facts are starting to emerge. Researchers at University of Southern California and UC Berkley have released their research into the (chilling) effects of the 'ceast and desist' type provisions contained within the bill. Ars Technica, as always, has a good write up on the issue.

The study shows some interesting results about who is issuing these summary notices and what their primary motivations are. Over 84% of the notices are sent to Google, not to the ISP hosting the material in question. While the removal of a Google link makes a site much more difficult to find, it does not remove the material from the Internet itself. Most of the corporations sending the notices are small Internet businesses. 55% of the notices sent to Google are requests to remove links to the complainant's direct business competitors. A surprisingly low 6% of notices were sent by the music and movie industry.


In a word - scary.

item.title: Sony DRM
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Perhaps you've heard about the issues surrounding Sony's latest attempt to stop you from illegally copying their precious copyright on your PC. To quickly catch you up to speed here is the skinny 411.

About six months ago Sony started shipping music CDs with a copy protection named XCP from a UK company called First4Internet. The problem being that this piece of software employs tactics commonly utilized by spyware/malware/virus writers to evade detection on your system. The XCP software installs a root-kit which hooks deeply into your system internals and prevents itself from being uninstalled. Now here are the bad parts:

1. The licence agreement (EULA) that you agree to when playing the CD makes no mention of the software
2. They provide no means to uninstall the software.
3. Attempting to uninstall the software yourself will result in a disabled CD drive in your computer.
4. Having the XCP rootkit running on your computer leaves your computer open to virus writers everywhere because the authors didn't write tight software and while stopping you from copying CDs also stops your antivirus program from successfully removing viruses aswell.
5. They previously made you jump through rings in order to even get anywhere near the download page for an uninstaller.
6. They are now providing an uninstaller, however the mechanism for removing the software (downloading via ActiveX from the first4internet webpage), leaves you totally vulnerable to any subsequent webpages you visit. Any website author with 10 min of free time can write a script to automatically install their particular brand of nasty virus/malware on your computer without your knowledge - just because you trusted first4internet to uninstall the rootkit that they originally put on your computer.

To top this all off the company first4internet have apparently been violating the GPL (open source sofware licence) of various software tools in their rootkit. Ironic isn't it that in the name of 'copyright protection' for Sony's music content they have been busy violating other people's copyrights.

You can read more about the issue by searching "sony rootkit" or by checking out this page fom sysintenals or this one from AP.

item.title: ITunes and variable pricing
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
You may have heard speculation recently that Apple is going to start releasing songs on iTunes under a variable pricing regime. Most of these rumors have come from the record label side of the fence and normally come with a "don't you want to pay less for your old favourites" type of message. There are a number of reasons why I think the labels are pushing this and I don't think me getting cheaper music is one of them.

Reason 1. People are (apparently) willing to pay upto $3-4 a song to get it on their phone and playing as their ringtone. The record labels would love to make you pay 3 times more for that new "hit" because its the one they've spend all this advertising money telling you you want.

Reason 2. Record labels are still producing albumns under an outdated model where the 2-3 good songs on an albumn would carry the abysmal shite that they use to fill out the rest of the 30-40 minutes. Now that you can pick and choose which songs you want that model is falling flat on its face and they are trying to plug the gap rather than actually producing quality music that you will pay for. This also goes back to point 1 because it is easier to promote one or two good songs.

Reason 3. Price gives a percieved quality to an item. People tend to judge a product based on two criteria: 1) Brand - word of mouth and advertising play an important role in this. Have they heard of it before, will other people know about it, etc. 2) Price - if an item is priced higher people will give it more value in their mind. I've heard lots of anecdotal evidence of this (ie shop keep has a case of noname beer he can't move for weeks, he gets his pricing gun and ups the price four-fold and it's sold before the end of buisness). The labels need variable pricing to influence buying patterns (and recoup advertising costs). Joel on software (who i've never heard of before) has an interesting take on this.

In the end I'm always going to be wary of record labels like EMI, telling me they want to raise prices for my benefit. Incidently there has been no word (except that record labels are greedy) from Steve Jobs on this issue.

item.title: Happy Halloween
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Today is the official halloween and I'm sure that many a home owner is cleaning egg off their windows and wishing they had chosen 'treat' but for the older kids halloween actually happened on the weekend.

Chris and I got together a big crew for a party in Brooklyn, being as how we live in a different state this is a pretty long way to go for a party. But because we were travelling NJT (new jersey transit) we were able to drink for most of it :) Hell Chris even managed to take a can of beer through his beer funnel (yes on the train)



It was a pretty interesting night, I was dressed as a priest and (as could be expected) got plenty of "raped any little boys today?" type comments from randoms on the subway. From left to right in the picture are Colleen (new girl), Zina the stripper cop, ryan the ghoul, Joy the naughty librarian, Chris as Frank the tank, Krysten as Jackie-O and me as the chlid molestor.

After we got all the way down to Brooklyn and the girls figured out that they had pretty much come with the only three straight guys in the party were quickly looking to leave for "greener pastures". But the three of us - Ryan, Chris and I stayed and had an absolute blast, there were some very cool and interesting people there - the host was a friend of Chris' from when he was in high school in Cairo and there was a nicely diverse crowd. Zina had her camera so I'm hoping she can provide me with some photographic evidence of the nights adventures. Will post more pics as soon as I have them.

Also I am thinking about moving this blog to blogger so that people can leave comments - if you are reading this and would ever do such a thing drop me a quick email at jimi _ cook at yahoo

item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Seasons greetings to you all. I hope everyone is having as great a Chrissie as I am, I'm back in Australia, seeing my mates, my family and enjoying some beautiful weather. I am staying with my little sister up at my mum's house on the Sunshine coast (1 1/2 hours north of Brisbane). It is now boxing day and I'm sitting down after a big lunch and watching the boxing day test match, Australia is playing South Africa and so far doing pretty well at 1/147.
This afternoon I'm hoping to get down the beach and then perhaps play a bit of backyard cricket with my mates. Loving life!!!!

item.title: Back at QUT
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Well today is my second day back in the lab here at QUT and I've managed to get some processing running which looks like it will take quite a while. I'm not really sure what I'm going to do while I wait for it to finish so I decided to post here instead, plus I'm hoping this will stop me thinking about lunch which is still an hour away :(

You might have noticed that the dates on my last posts were a little misleading, I wrote the posts while flying back to Aus (coz I had nothing better to do on the flight) and posted them when I returned from my holiday... I mean work trip to Cairns :) I landed in Brisvegas on Sunday the 4th of Dec and then jumped a flight up to Cairns on the Monday for the DICTA conference. I had to present two papers (one of my own and one from Sarnoff), and both presentations went well despite a lack of preparation. I have to say that the Cairns convention center provided excellent facilities for the event and really are a top notch venue, the food was good, the space was bright and airy and the staff friendly (plus free wireless internet which I enjoyed). Gill came up with me and we stayed in a decent hotel a short walk from the esplanade, which provided some great opportunities for fine dining.

After the conference was done, Gill and I headed out of town and South to Tully, which is a town which boasts the highest rainfall in Queensland and the largest banana plantation in the southern hemisphere. We were camped about 20km south of the town at this gorgeous camping ground right beside this incredible waterfall (Murray Falls), we took a few pics and posted them to flickr but here are some of the better ones.



It really was so peaceful up there it is hard to describe in words, just try imagining waking up in a nice shady spot to clear blue skys and hearing the sound of falling water in the background. That'l get you close to how good it is.

Tully also has a massive gorge behind it which has white water rapids and is enclosed by pristine rainforest. One side is a national park and the other is heritage listed rainforest. We went down with this company that does all day rafting tours, we had a funny Canadian girl steering us (and yelling at us) as we zipped down the rapids (and in one case into the rapids - but we were rescued quickly by the other boats). They stopped after a few hours and put on a great BBQ lunch, well it tasted great after all the hard yakka we'd been doing all morning anyway, then it was off for an afternoon of more paddling. Gill and I both ended up with real bad sunburn on our knees (as did most everyone else) and I had a cracker of a burn line from my sandals. But all in all we would do it all over again in a heartbeat, that pretty much seemed to be the buzz from other rafters in the pub afterwards too :)

Well those are my adventures in getting back into Australia I've got more stories from my mate Liam's birthday / my return party which I shall post shortly (complete with photo evidence).

item.title: Crazy Farewell
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Last night we had a great farewell party, starting out with dinner at a Mexican restaurant and then moving back to our apartment. In attendance were Tesh, Maite, Matt Hopkins, Aveek, Ryan, Joy, Zina, Chris, Megan, Summer, Matt Pancione and Kristin. A few more people (Kacey, Jim) turned up after we got back from the restaurant and it was really sweet to have a good chance to mix with everyone before I flew out. Chris even bullied everyone into saying something nice about me, it was such a great moment and is something that I am going to remember for a long time (also Maite got it on video). It really made me feel special and it also made me realize how much Im going to miss everyone when I get back home. Lots of love to you guys if you are reading this now!
I wont go into the sordid details of the rest of the night but there were some shenanigans back at our favourite local the Ivy. It was< totally dead and we brought the party with us, the owner giving us free shots of Jagermeister all night helped to get the party started as well. He also gave me that last Ivy t-shirt as well which will be something to reminisce about when I get home. Matt tried to buy one for me as a going away present earlier but they had sold out of them and only had the display one hanging behind the bar which thanks to Rich I am now the proud owner of <font face="Wingdings">J</font>.
Thanks to everyone who came out to make it such a memorable night.

item.title: Happy New Years
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Well the new year is upon us and it has taken me this long to get around to posting up my first message of 2006. Lots has been happening since the last time I posted so I'll go over them all real quick.

First up I got real sick just after christmas and had to spend two days in bed which wasn't exactly how I had imagined my holidays and I was in doubt about whether I'd be in a fit state to go up to woodford. However I got better in time for Gll's arrival on the coast and we were able to leave for the festival the next day. It was stinking hot up there as normal and we were all very glad that my friend Liam and little brother Gareth had already set up a kick ass camp site for us to slot into. We spent a great three days up there checking out all the cool bands and work shops - Gill and I did an etheopian dancing workshop which left our calves burning for days afterwards.

I've got a couple of photos this year, but for the most part I was thinking more about the festival and less about photos.




After woodford I just sort of bummed around the house for a couple of days getting things set up around the place. Got a new wireless router and spent an afternoon setting that up to work with my adsl modem. Not as much fun as the time up in woodford for some, but for me a worthy diversion of my time :)

While I'm in a picture posting mode I'll also post a couple from my homecoming party (also Liam's birthday). We had it on the Sunday after we got back from Cairns and had a really awesome night, my friend Leah was in town from Melbourne and we got to have a good catch up. Played charades for about 2 hours and drank like fish, good times.

Liam's friend Sarah baked him this awesome guitar cake which he proceeded to eat like he was jimi hendrix.

From the demo I could think of a couple of enhancements, namely there should only be one image full sized at a time, if you click on a second it should minimize the first one. And why does it even need to be a click - mouseover should work just as well.

item.title: Just deserts for talking while driving
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
The following is ripped directly from the wired gadgets blog.

In a car crash that perfectly illustrates the importance of hands-free mobile devices, a Kentucky woman flipped her truck after veering into the median, and severed her arm in the crash. Fortunately, the woman and her six-year-old daughter survived the crash, and paramedics were able to locate the woman's severed arm, which was found still clutching the phone she was talking on when the crash began. The woman was flown to the hospital in serious condition. Use your headsets, people!

"Thank you for being a loyal consumer of Miller Brewing Company. As one of our VIP consumers, you have likely received email communications from us in the past. Recently, however, we have not been able to deliver email messages to the address you originally supplied. We have performed an electronic change of address to update our records so that we can continue to send you special offers, promotions, and announcements via email."

item.title: Robot Slime
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded: A while back I saw an article describing how scientists had connected a flight simulator to a petri dish of rat brain cells and that those cells were doing a passable job of keeping the flight simulator running on a smooth course. Well it appears that these scientists from Japan have gone one step further with this approach and have build a robot which is controlled by a light sensitive type of slime mould. Thats right this little six legged robot will scuttle away from bright lights and find itself a dark humid corner to hide it.... weird but true.

item.title: Digital Photography
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Today I finally got my christmas present from Gill, a digital photography workshop with the guys she works for. And I have to say it was worth waiting for, they put on a really helpful and useful presentation which really helped me get a good grasp on the fundamentals of digital photography, esp how the appeture (f/stop), shutter speed and ISO sensitivity inter-relate to one another.

I am thinking I'll also go along to their advanced workshop in a fortnights time aswell. It also didn't hurt that they lived in a beautiful setting out at Karana downs, they have the most incredible view out on to the river from their back deck which is just priceless. These are two shots I took pointed back up towards their house and I'm trying to decide which is a better shot.




Oh and if you are interested in taking a class in digital photography I'd recommend getting in contact with them via their website.

item.title: Zombie Cockroaches
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded: This would have to be one of the sickest weirdest things I've seen for a long time, apparently there a genus of wasp which has developed the ability to produce a venom which turns cockroaches into unthinking zombies which it can then lead back to the wasp nest to become the hatching ground for the wasp's larvae. I kid you not!!

item.title: Robot Donkey
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded: The things the US  military comes up with, the description paints an impressive picture and seems to be a fairly nifty autonomous vehicle - I wonder if it's max capacity (40kg) will rise in the future to a point where you could ride one of these things? It also fits in rather nicely with the little known fact (which I read on the citycat going to work the other day) that "US have never lost a war when donkeys were used" . Now that they have robot donkeys they'll be unstoppable.

item.title: The Michealangelo Code
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
If you've read the Da Vinci code or heard about the current court case playing out in the states in which Dan Brown is being accused of plagarising most of the DaVinci code from another book then this parody site is worth a look (and a laugh).

Dr. Franklin Harvard awoke to the sound of his "Ass like that" ringtone. His eyes pinched against the green glare of the LCD screen and the display that said "Private Number".

"Hello?" he grumbled.

The voice that came down the line sounded vaguely European. Considering he was in Europe, this was unsurprising.

"Dr. Harvard, this is Chief Inspector Jaques Deschanel from some special but fairly incompetent French Police unit. I am stubborn and short tempered, and don't like to rely on outside help. I'll be brisk and abrupt with you, but when we solve this case I'll look you deep in the eyes, shake your hands and say 'thank you' so the reader will know to like me in the sequel."

item.title: Nerd Test
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded: Well, I scored even higher on this than I thought I would. Supreme Nerd is me eh?

item.title: Google Calendar
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
I know I just posted about google's new voice search but this announcement is really one I've been hanging out for a for a long time. I found this service back when it was still in invite only beta and I've been hanging to get my hands on it ever since.

I've used the MS outlook calendar application before for quite some time but now that I'm on and off both my laptop and my work computer it got too hard to keep them synchronized and I'd be working on one and miss events from the other. So lets just say I'm stoked about the google calendar and it's automated email integration - I check my email often enough that this will actually keep me on time for appointments.

Check it out at www.google.com/calendar

item.title: Google Voice Search
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
I'm a sucker for new google products and it looks (at least to me) like this one has some great potential. Google has been trying to crack into the localalised search market with their local offering in NY which will serve up local pizzerias from appropriately enabled mobile phones and with their new positional tracking system in San Francisco where they are teaming up with Earthlink to provide free WiFi internet to the city.

I think that if they are able to put together a good interface (something they are renowned for) for this it could really drive adoption of google search as an application thought of synonmously with mobile phones.

item.title: $100 Laptop Prototype
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
If you haven't been following the story, the $100 laptop is an initiative cooked up by millionaire philanthropist Nicholas Negroponte to provide cheap laptops to kids in Africa. That is a very condensed version of the story, but it is the essence - check out the official site for more information.

The rhetoric and opinions have been flying over this program ever since it was first announced but now I am happy to say that there is a physical product which we can all "ooohhh and aahhh" over - MIT has produced the first prototypes of the $100 laptop and pictures are available at (and it makes me very happy to say it) flickr.


Photos taken by Pete Barr-Watson at the OLPC meeting

item.title: Google Maps does Australia
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded: For all those who feel as if we've been missing out on the love here down under, despair no more google maps has finally come to the party. Big props to cebidae for breaking this one before the official google blog did. It also appears as if the database has had some extra high zoom scans added to it since the last time I checked.

item.title: Airport Security
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
I just saw a couple of articles on a company called Vidient, who are in the process of rolling out their SmartCatch technology to the international airport in Helsinki. They claim to offer the ability to "automatically monitors CCTV footage and can recognise potential security threats. It also flags up operational issues such as building queues and bottlenecks of human traffic through customs and security."

They have also been behind government funded program to incorporate the same smart surveillance technology in San Francisco International. Asked about whether this system had ever actually stopped any known terrorists airport security manager Paul Foster replied "Did I stop a bad guy or did I just stop an employee from doing something they shouldn't be doing? I can't be certain. People in security look at things differently." Well dodged!

item.title: Google Releases AJAX Framework
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded: If like me you've been impressed with the spiffyness of the recent spate of google applications such as Gmail, Maps, Notebook etc... but don't have the faintest idea on how you could possibly make web applications to rival them then good news is at hand. Google have recently announced that they will be releasing their Google Web Toolkit (GWT) which promises to allow developers to write java code which will be auto-translated into cross-browser compatible ajax code. Neat-O!!!!

item.title: More Sydney
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Been having a chill out day today. Gill has been at work teaching kids whatever it is that she teaches them so I have been left to my own devices, that means wandering around downtown Sydney and drinking coffee in a variety of locales. It is now 3:30 in the afternoon so I though I'd take a few minutes to catch up on my web reading and blogging. Geez you leave the internet for 4 days and suddenly you have over 250 new articles collected in your intray, will have to spend a large portion of my day when I get home going through them all... no way I'm going to get it all sorted while I'm paying $3/hr for internet access. Been lamenting my lack of reading material while I've been down here and this morning decided to pick up a copy of L. Ron Hubbards "The Invasion Plan" from the "Mission Earth" series. Hubbard is an author who has been recommended to me on any number of occasions by fans who are bigger into the Sci-Fi genre than I am so I have finally decided to give the guy a go, but as you can see from the below cover it doesn't exactly look like the greatest literary accomplishment of the modern age. I esp dislike the red italicized font used for "Mission Earth" - super tacky. But from the first 50 or so pages that I've read it appears to be a decent read - only nine books in the series so I'll have a full review for you all in a week - j/k.
Well now I am off to do some quick last minute surfing before my time runs out then off for some spannish tapas with Gill for my last night in town back in Brisbane tomorrow morning.

item.title: Sydney
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
item.content:encoded:
Its been a great couple of days, I've spend the last four nights in Sydney for the biometrics consortium annual conference. I flew down on Thursday morning and despite a small snafu with forgetting the poster that I was due to present that morning everything worked out fairly well. Spent the next two days being pretty bored at what was a very vendor/government dominated event but made up for it with a great weekend of shopping and cafes in the city and in funky Newtown. I brought my camera down but haven't taken very many photos so will try and make it up in the last couple of days down here. I fly back this Thursday so I have a couple of days.

Gill is doing some work down in Sydney so she has been here since last friday, and will be staying for two weeks. We've been kicking around together doing a lot of shopping and siteseeing (and a lot of eating). She has a half day today so we are going to spend some of it looking around Redfern (don't ask how I ended up in Redfern) and surrounding suburbs before heading back to Kings Cross to complete our tour of the unsavoury regions of Sydney :)

item.dc:creator: jamiecook

item.title: Boys will be boys
item.dc:creator: jamiecook
